Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the "2018 Spring Redbud Topology Conference", to be held on April 28-29, 2018 on the campus of Oklahoma State University in Stillwater, Oklahoma. The confernece will be preceded by a one-day graduate workshop to be held on April 27. The conference will bring together experts in the fields of 3-manifold and 4-manifold topology -- i.e., features
(like 'holes') that remain unchanged when these spaces are bent or stretched -- to discuss natural ways of breaking these objects into more well understood pieces. The list of committed speakers includes researchers based in Australia, Asia and the US. This award will provide funding for their travel as well as US based graduate students and other early career mathematicians wishing to attend the meetings.

Two main areas of research will be presented at the Spring 2018 conference, namely triangulations of 3- and 4-manifolds and trisections, a recently introduced combinatorial decomposition of 4-manifolds. In the triangulations thread, the focus will be on current algorithmic questions related to 3-manifold topology. We will also focus on recent developments in trisections, including basic constructions of trisections arising from gluing, invariants which can be calculated from trisections, and applications of trisections in mathematical physics. By bringing these groups of experts together, participants will explore and extend very recently discovered connections between 4-dimensional trisections and triangulations. Ten speakers will be featured during the conference as well as introductory talks during the graduate workshop. The conference webpage can be found at:

http://math.okstate.edu/conferences/redbud/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project brought together domestic and international experts in the field of low dimensional topology who study 3 and 4 dimensional objects and spaces. The main activities funded by the grant were a graduate student conference (5 graduate student speakers and a department colloquium) and a main conference (8 speakers). 


Intellectual Merit: Our focus was to ask basic questions about how to enumerate 4 dimensional spaces using a cutting edge construction called a trisection, which breaks a 4 dimensional space into to three pieces in a specific way. The interfaces of these pieces are 3 dimensional spaces and so the other aspect of our conference was to bring in experts in that field as well. Several of our speakers have contributed foundational results and were able to utilize their expertise to concretely describe what is known and unknown about the central problems in the field. This is especially important as a majority of our audience was comprised of early career mathematicians: graduate students and post-doctoral researchers. 

Broader impacts: The broader impacts of the project were to provide opportunities for early carreer mathematicians to present their results and hear about an emerging area of study. The activities began with five graduate student talks and a department colloquium. The main conference had eight speakers (including the colloquium speaker giving a second, field specific talk). Over all we had four female speakers and nine of our speakers were graduate students or post-doctoral researchers. We also one speaker from private industry. Our conference attendance twenty-one faculty members (17 male, 4 female), five post-doctoral researchers (4 male, 1 female), twenty-three students (15 male, 8 female), and participant from industry (1 male). 

Outcomes: This conference is part of a shared committment from the topology groups of the University of Oklahoma, Oklahoma State University and the University of Arkansas to hold regular meetings encouraging the interaction between students at our institutions and institutions in the region to participate in high level research activities. Overall researchers from 17 different institutions participated in the conference.
